quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Character and Movie
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, drama, pink. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Indian Ink comes from what country?
Which U.S. President attempted to purchase Cuba from Spain?
Since 1815, Switzerland has been involved in only a few wars because of its policy of neutrality.
What was the name of Margaret Mitchell’s only book written in 1936?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gone With The Wind

questions.question: A character, played by which of these actors/actresses survived in the movie The Poseidon Adventure?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red Buttons

questions.question: This novel written by German author Herman Hesse was published in 1922.
Devils on Horseback is a type of food.
The pink ball is worth 6 points in the game of snooker.
In the movie Armageddon, the character played by Ben Affleck takes the place of Harry S. Stamper, portrayed by Bruce Willis and detonates the bomb that splits the asteroid in two.
What infectious disease can be transmitted by a mosquito bite?
Which cast member of the TV drama Dallas starred in the film Earthquake?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Victoria Principal

questions.question: Who invented the first working television system?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Logie Baird

questions.question: Great Britains first test tube baby was born in what year?
The character played by which of these actors/actresses did not survive in the disaster movie The Towering Inferno?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert Wagner

questions.question: This term of Indian origin refers to ones fate or destiny, as the result of ones actions.

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Movie and Books
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, rooms, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which actor/actress who starred in the film The Poseidon Adventure appeared in the TV series The Hardy Boys/Nancy Drew Mysteries?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pamela Sue Martin

questions.question: What was the cause of the fire in the movie The Towering Inferno?

options.text: Short circuit in the elevator shaft
A loose lid on a can of kerosene stored in a closet

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Faulty electrical wiring

questions.question: The Peace Symbol, which became an icon of the 1960s anti-war movement, derives from what?

options.text: an image of a nuclear bomber

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: two semaphoric signals

questions.question: Which one of these actors/actresses did not star in the movie Earthquake?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fred Astaire

questions.question: Who played the last juror to vote not  guilty in the 1957 movie Twelve Angry Men?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lee J. Cobb

questions.question: Which was the first country to win two consecutive FIFA World Cups in 1958 and 1962?
You go into a diner and  you hear the  waitress yell out Cats Eyes. What has someone just ordered?

options.text: a breakfast of steak and two eggs

questions.question: A cat that was trapped in one of the burning rooms in The Towering Inferno was rescued by security guard played by  O.J. Simpson.
According to the Christian  tradition there are 39 books in the Old Testament. How many books are there in the Old Testament according to the Jewish tradition?
Jose Raul Capablanca of Cuba was the first person from the Western Hemisphere to do what?

options.text: Be President of the U.N. General  Assembly
Win the Nobel Prize for Literature

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Win the World Chess Championship

questions.question: What contributed to the quick tipping over of the luxury ocean liner in the movie The Poseidon Adventure?

options.text: Shelley Winters was too close to the starboard side of the boat
Not enough speed when the wall of water hit
Engines were at full power too long so they shut down

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: There was not enough ballast

questions.question: Why was a performance by Bob Dylan interrupted in 1998?

options.text: A shirtless man with the words Soy Bomb written on his chest leapt on stage.
His lyrics did not pass the decency level required by CBS Television.
Tom Petty had not made it into the stage in time to play the musical bridge in the song.
The show ran 15 minutes over and ABC Television had gone to the evening news.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A shirtless man with the words Soy Bomb written on his chest leapt on stage.

questions.question: What was the special speaker system used during the 1974 theatrical release of the movie Earthquake?
Which battleship was used by the US Navy during World War II, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: USS New Jersey (BB-62)

questions.question: Which of these famous people  was not an epileptic?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Otto von Bismarck

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Patent and Word
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, iraq, pilgrimage. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which if these is an area in Iraq, and a pilgrimage place for some Muslims?
Who invented the doll that says Momma?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alexander Graham Bell

questions.question: In this 2005 documentary film a  large number of famous comedians show how they tell one particular dirty joke.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Aristocrats

questions.question: To whom did the inventor of the typewriter sell his patent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A maker of guns

questions.question: Which US President invented the baseball seventh inning stretch?
Which song was Billy Joels first US Top Ten Hit?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Just the Way You Are

questions.question: Which of the following animals is the odd one?
Who wrote the opera Mozart et Salieri?
What is the mathematical term for the shape of a footballs path, when thrown form one player to another?
Who was the first Major League Baseball player born in what was then called Czechoslovakia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elmer Valo

questions.question: The Magna Carta went into effect in 1215.  Who signed it?
Who is the only President who had a patent?
Where does the word Rastafarian come from?

options.text: It comes from a Taino name
The real name of a king

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The real name of a king

questions.question: Find the odd one.
Where did the word Melba come from, as in Melba toast and Peach Melba?

options.text: The name of the wife of the owner of Cunard Cruise Line.
The name of  the proprietress of Del Monicos Steak House.
The name of Henry Fords wife
The name of an Australian singer

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The name of an Australian singer

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Following and Planet
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, weight, angels. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which planet is 5th from the sun?
Which of the following months is the odd one?
Which of the following is the the odd one?
How old was Bobby Fischer when he won the US chess championship on January 8th 1958?
Name the odd one.
What was the previous name of the Los Angeles Dodgers?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Brooklyn Dodgers

questions.question: Which of these is the the odd one?
Which of these names the odd one?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ferdinand Marcos

questions.question: Which of these is the odd one out?
What would you be eating if you were served Angels on Horseback?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oysters wrapped in bacon

questions.question: Which number is the odd one out?
September 3rd through 13th in the year 1752 did not exist.
What is another name for Ursa Major?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Great Bear

questions.question: There are only 10 weight classes in male professional boxing.
Which of the animals listed below has the longest gestation period?

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Country and Television
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, patron, programming. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In 1958, Pope Pius XII designated an Italian saint as the patron saint for television.
Who killed Achilles according to Greek mythology?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Paris aided by Apollo

questions.question: On the popular TV show The Honeymooners, Ralph worked as a bus driver for this fictional company.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gotham Bus Company

questions.question: This red herbivorous mammal is endangered because of habitat loss and human interference.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lesser Panda

questions.question: This programming language that allowed non-scientists to use computers was developed in 1963 by John Kemeny and Thomas Kurtz.
Who won the 1958 Academy Award for Best Actress?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Susan Hayward

questions.question: What singer won the 1958 Grammy Award for Best Male Vocal Performance?

options.text: Perry Como for the song Catch a Falling Star
Bobby Darin for the song Dream Lover
Domenico Mondugno for the song Nel Blu Dipinto
Dick Dale for the song Lets Go Tripping

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Perry Como for the song Catch a Falling Star

questions.question: When was Kevin Bacon born?
How much did Harvard Universitys tuition and fees total for the 1958-1959 school year?
Hammerfest, which is often referred to as the northernmost town in Europe, is located in this Scandinavian country.
The person who developed the popular game Sudoku was from which country?
Which one of these statements was not made by economist Milton Friedman?

options.text: Hell hath no fury like a bureaucrat scorned.
Inflation is one form of taxation that can be  imposed without legislation.
For the bureaucrat the world is  a mere object to be manipulated by him.
Governments never learn. Only people learn.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: For the bureaucrat the world is  a mere object to be manipulated by him.

questions.question: Who was Vice President under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, when the Alaska Statehood Act was signed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard Nixon

questions.question: How large is one micron?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: one millionth of a meter

questions.question: Which Latin expression means actions speak louder than words?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: facta non verba

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Poet and Policy
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, john, policy. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The first screen kiss was seen in the short movie The Kiss, shown in what year?
This form of traditional Japanese theater, which aims to make the audience laugh, is characterised by brief plays, stock characters and exaggerated dialogue.
Which French artist is considered the founder of Fauvism?
This Spanish playwright and poet, author of The Dog in the Manger and The Widow from Valencia,  maintained that a writers business is to write so as to make himself understood.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lope de Vega

questions.question: The newton (N), named after Sir Isaac Newton in recognition of his work on classical mechanics, is a unit measuring what?

This small, distinct religious community, whose religion resembles Islam, but is influenced by Greek philosophy and other religions, is based mostly in the Middle East. Its members call themselves the People of Monotheism.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Druze

questions.question: Which of these events came first?

options.text: The completion of he first standardized French dictionary
The completion of the first standard English dictionary
The completion of he first standardized Italian dictionary
The first use of the word scientist

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The completion of he first standardized Italian dictionary

questions.question: How many prime numbers are smaller than 23?

This English shipbuilder, merchant and navigator, whose innovative measures made the new English ships fast and highly maneuverable, was one of the main commanders of the English fleet against the Spanish Armada in 1588.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Hawkins

questions.question: Which of these is the last name of the two brothers who have each won the Cy Young Award given to the best Major League Baseball pitchers?
He reigned until 1725 and carried out a policy of Westernization and expansion, that transformed his country into a major European power.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peter the Great

questions.question: John Howard Lawson, Herbert Biberman, Albert Maltz, Adrian Scott, Sam Ornitz, Dalton Trumbo, Ed Dmytryk, Ring Lardner Jr, Alvah Bessie, and Lester Cole made short speeches to denounce McCarthyism. All of them belonged to a group, known by what name?

options.text: The ten spies of the CIA
The ten players of Dr. James Naismith
The ten judges at the Nuremburg Trials

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Hollywood Ten

questions.question: This Dutch naval officer, who became a folk hero during the Eighty Years War between the Dutch republic and Spain, sailed out to capture the Spanish treasure fleet in 1628.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pieter Heyn

questions.question: Which month is United States Aquarium Month, Candy Month, Dairy Month and Turkey Lovers Month?
When Lincoln delivered his Gettysburg Address he was not  the main speaker. Who was the main speaker?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Edward Everett
